segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 47
segments.en: Linked Discourses 47

segments.pli: 1. Ambapālivagga
segments.en: 1. In Ambapālī’s Wood

segments.pli: 6. Sakuṇagghisutta
segments.en: 6. A Hawk

segments.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi lāpaṃ sakuṇaṃ sahasā ajjhappattā aggahesi.
segments.en: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a hawk suddenly swooped down and grabbed a quail.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, lāpo sakuṇo sakuṇagghiyā hariyamāno evaṃ paridevasi:
segments.en: And as the quail was being carried off he wailed,

segments.pli: ‘mayamevamha alakkhikā, mayaṃ appapuññā, ye mayaṃ agocare carimha paravisaye.
segments.en: ‘I’m so unlucky, so unfortunate, to have roamed out of my territory into the domain of others.

segments.pli: Sacejja mayaṃ gocare careyyāma sake pettike visaye, na myāyaṃ, sakuṇagghi, alaṃ abhavissa, yadidaṃ—yuddhāyā’ti.
segments.en: If today I’d roamed within my own territory, the domain of my fathers, this hawk wouldn’t have been able to beat me by fighting.’

segments.pli: ‘Ko pana te, lāpa, gocaro sako pettiko visayo’ti?
segments.en: ‘So, quail, what is your own territory, the domain of your fathers?’

segments.pli: ‘Yadidaṃ—naṅgalakaṭṭhakaraṇaṃ leḍḍuṭṭhānan’ti.
segments.en: ‘It’s a ploughed field covered with clods of earth.’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi sake bale apatthaddhā sake bale asaṃvadamānā lāpaṃ sakuṇaṃ pamuñci:
segments.en: Confident in her own strength, the hawk was not daunted or intimidated. She released the quail, saying,

segments.pli: ‘gaccha kho tvaṃ, lāpa, tatrapi me gantvā na mokkhasī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Go now, quail. But even there you won’t escape me!’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, lāpo sakuṇo naṅgalakaṭṭhakaraṇaṃ leḍḍuṭṭhānaṃ gantvā mahantaṃ leḍḍuṃ abhiruhitvā sakuṇagghiṃ vadamāno aṭṭhāsi:
segments.en: Then the quail went to a ploughed field covered with clods of earth. He climbed up a big clod, and standing there, he said to the hawk:

segments.pli: ‘ehi kho dāni me, sakuṇagghi, ehi kho dāni me, sakuṇagghī’ti.
segments.en: ‘Come get me, hawk! Come get me, hawk!’

segments.pli: Atha kho sā, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi sake bale apatthaddhā sake bale asaṃvadamānā ubho pakkhe sannayha lāpaṃ sakuṇaṃ sahasā ajjhappattā.
segments.en: Confident in her own strength, the hawk was not daunted or intimidated. She folded her wings and suddenly swooped down on the quail.

segments.pli: Yadā kho, bhikkhave, aññāsi lāpo sakuṇo ‘bahuāgato kho myāyaṃ sakuṇagghī’ti, atha tasseva leḍḍussa antaraṃ paccupādi.
segments.en: When the quail knew that the hawk was nearly there, he slipped under that clod.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi tattheva uraṃ paccatāḷesi.
segments.en: But the hawk crashed chest-first right there.

segments.pli: Evañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yo agocare carati paravisaye.
segments.en: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, mā agocare carittha paravisaye.
segments.en: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.

segments.pli: Agocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ paravisaye lacchati māro otāraṃ, lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
segments.en: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will find a vulnerability and get hold of you.

segments.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo?
segments.en: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?

segments.pli: Yadidaṃ—pañca kāmaguṇā.
segments.en: It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: Katame pañca?
segments.en: What five?

segments.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
segments.en: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: sotaviññeyyā saddā … pe …
segments.en: Sounds known by the ear …

segments.pli: ghānaviññeyyā gandhā … pe …
segments.en: Smells known by the nose …

segments.pli: jivhāviññeyyā rasā … pe …
segments.en: Tastes known by the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
segments.en: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

segments.pli: ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo.
segments.en: This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.

segments.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
segments.en: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.

segments.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ sake pettike visaye na lacchati māro otāraṃ, na lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
segments.en: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t find a vulnerability or get hold of you.

segments.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo?
segments.en: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?

segments.pli: Yadidaṃ—
cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
segments.en: It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

segments.pli: Katame cattāro?
segments.en: What four?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: vedanāsu … pe …
segments.en: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: citte … pe …
segments.en: mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo”ti.
segments.en: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”

segments.pli: Chaṭṭhaṃ.

sections.title: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a hawk suddenly swooped…

suttaplex.blurb: The parable of the quail and the hawk. When the quail ventured outside her ancestral territory, she became vulnerable. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
